bibl.title: Chung Him and Seid Yam v. Henry M. White. Warrant for Deportation of Chung Him
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: To Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Wash.,

WHEREAS, from proofs submitted to me, after due hearing before Immigrant Inspector William G. Strench, held at Ketchikan, Alaska, I have become satisfied that the alien Chung Him, who landed at the port of and unknown port, on or about the 1st day of June, 1916, has been found in the United States in violation of the immigration act of February 5, 1917, to wit:
That he has been found employed by, in, or in connection with a house of prostitution, and may be deported in accordance therewith:

I, Louis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of Labor, by virtue of the power and authority vested in me by the laws of the United States, do hereby command you to return the said alien to the country whence he came, at the appropriation "Expenses of Regulating Immigration, 1921." You are expense of the purchase transportation for the alien from Seattle, Wash., to such place in China as you may designate, at the lowest available rate, payable from the above named appropriation.
For so doing, this shall be your sufficient warrant.
Witness my hand and seal this 22nd day of July, 1920.
Dethrone China Chung Him, emplead. Deputize Seattle.
Exact Copy as Signed By Louis F. Post
OFFICIAL COPY furnished the Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Wash. Formal warrant mailed your office today. Alien will be conveyed to your port for detention pending deportation.
Exact Copy as Signed by Alfred Hampton
